text: Okay - finished!
Are you satisfied?
Hmmmm - that is a tough question.
I have thoughts.
I think a lot will depend on next season
But next season is a new story
It's true - and that's part of what I'm wondering.
I don't want to say too much here - I know Karen is on this channel and I don't think she's finished it.
But what they do with next season will play a part in how I feel about this one.
SPOILERS: <http://www.wekeeptheotherbadmenfromthedoor.com/#intro>

attachments.text: A very graphic representation of HBO's True Detective by Nigel Evan Dennis
attachments.fallback: A very graphic representation of HBO's True Detective by Nigel Evan Dennis

text: wow
someone put some time into that
right?
yes! that site is rad
i, for one, was satisfied with the finale
yeah?
Agree.
I conflicted about it
the last three episodes were so disconnected from the rest of the show
yeah - KAREN DONT READ THIS!!!
any way
can we jut suggest that Karen not follow the channel until she’s done? There’s not much to say that isn’t a spoiler...
yeah - I think thats a good call
so Im left thinking:
1) This was a show about the damage damaged people do those around them
and on that level, I really enjoyed it. There is nothing mystical or spiritual about that, and the symbols we evoke are just our way of trying to mask the fundamental reality of the situation
thats the interpretation I like the most

my problem is that, for me, the show didn’t feel self aware enough of the disintegration of the symbolism. In this way - even though I really want to believe the “answer” is option 1, it don’t feel 100% right to me
so then I have option 2) which is that The King in Yellow was a book of short stories that all revolved around the eponymous play
and that while each season will be different - like the book - they’ll all revolved around core mythology
and that this season was just table setting
I like this one the best aesthetically. It allows for the trajectory of season 1, without making all the symbolism red harrings.
we can also delete spoiler-y messages
true
I also have option 3) all the stuff Rusty was spouting was purely aesthetic, and the writer worked himself into a corner he couldn’t get out of and just made a run for it
From what I know about the writer, that doesn’t seem totally on target, but it wouldn’t be the first time a writer found terrific wallpaper with no house to put it in
at any rate, I’m reading the King in Yellow on the flight to france. I have high hopes

One of the things I like about option 1 is that, in the very best case, it folds the existential horror in on itself: that whats terrifying isn’t that we don’t understand the nature of universe, but that we understand it entirely
Protip: There are only like 2 stories in the king in yellow that are any good
I was afraid of that
I think what you're seeing on Cohle is a man who over time finally learns to deal with the loss of his child to a tragedy
while hart is losing his children to his own problems
all while trying to save children and women to atone
the "unfinished business"

yeah - I think thats right. What I’m left questioning is: its fine for the theoretical physics/philosophy of science stuff end up hollow - but if that’s the case, it has to be in service to the narrative, not an arbitrary reaction to.
Im still left wondering at the extent to which the writer was in control of his own story here
I don’t need that characters to be aware of whats happening - I’d prefer they’re not - but I do need the author to be
so while I think you’re 100% on point, I’m left wondering: what was the point of telling me time is circle, when clearly - in the scope of this season, it’s anything but
<@U026AP8CM|karen> has left the channel
Well, Rust's bullshit is largely him being walled off to any real connection with people cause he's hurt so bad by his losses
So he has this affected (ahem, why do i know this?) distance rooted in a bunch of topics and opinions that are out of reach or off-putting to anyone who tries to get close
sure - but why THOSE topics.
Cause they're morbid

and I guess Im getting into my art history stuff here: but the choices an artists make are important. Rust could have just been closed off and silent, or he could be spouting m-theory stuff, or he could be obsessed with gore, or whatever - but I think the artist should have a reason for the choice they make
I've backed off of looking for more in the character other than "sad dude. doesn't want to talk about it. doesn't think he deserves to have fun or friends."
that’s probably smart. FWIW the half life of me trying to dissect this is about a week. So by the time I get back I should be less wound up
hahahah, it doesn't get easier. Mainly cause you really can read metaphysics into it.
There's a scene tho that i think is really important when cohle goes to that dude's house
to ask about his nephew
er his song
son
the guy with the shotgun?
and the dude says like two sentences, lives alone, and tells rust to leave
yeah
yeah
same loss as rust
Child, wife.
And oddly, i never thought about that scene before right now.

yeah - see this what I’m all wound about: is this a show about nothing having meaning? OR is a show where things are meaningless? Because I think that’s an important distinction. I THINK it’s meant to be the first - which I like as a goal, but think the show faltered in execution towards it
Like - was that scene meant be symbolic of something? Because it sure felt like it was.
I started reading the King in Yellow. Didn’t finish it. Not worth it for me.
I think its a show about misdirected responsibility
interesting. All this is why Im so hyped for next season
with just one data point I feel like I can’t ground anything. Next season will create a trajectory for the show
Well its an anthology series, so next series has no connection to the first.
But stylistically yeah, there should be more to mine

Well - “anthology” doesn’t mean there is no connection. Im not saying it will be a direct line, but if I hear something about black stars or Carcosa next season, I won’t be shocked. But that aside, I suppose what I’m looking for even more is a sense of overarching intent
If next season really is about the occult influence in the transportation system - or wherever he said - then there is a theme established and makes it harder to say “none of this matters"

So look at it this way: were all well educated folk who don't fall for mass superstition or whacky other worldly evil conspiracy theories, right? But holy shit TD totally could have had me practicing Santeria to try to solve a thing I couldn't understand. So maybe that's what the show is also about: audience manipulation in a non-antihero way
Cause a lot of early reviews painted rust as an antihero, but is he? He's actually a really really good cop. He's not shady, just not personable
Oh yeah, I never felt that Rus was antihero at all
Whereas the real antihero is marty
oh absolutely
Cause he's basically human garbage to his family, but pops reg ladoux with barely a second thought in a moment of moral outrage
yeah - I mean the way I took it is that Marty is basically societies ego - and like our society he’s all ego
he’s all appearance and top level understanding of the world
Russ always seemed to me to be all id
he went into the basement and never came up
Marty nailed the basement door shut and let whatever was down there run wild
Or they're "walmart or target" amongst the audience
Bush and Obama, really
potato potahto
hahaha
Right, tho
Similar goal, different approach, same shit
<@U026NAD9A|shawn> has left the channel
I think they have overlapping goals in certain areas

I guess the conclusion I came to was the Marty was an avatar for society as we want it to be: outwardly he has all the things we’d want it to have: it’s clean, good humored, hardworking, nice family. But it’s so obsessed with preserving the facade and denying the existence of anything more chaotic that it literally cannot contemplate its own moral failings and the fact that all the artifice it claims is important is crumbling around it
As with Marty, so with the community he inhabits
A file was shared
!! I need that
<https://www.facebook.com/popmediaillustrated>

those are terrific!
